subject: Art
title: Local vs Observed Color
description: The color you think something is vs the color you actually see.

hook.text: An apple is red ‚Äî right? But in blue moonlight, that apple is purple. In warm candlelight, it's orange-red. The 'real' color of an object depends entirely on the light hitting it.

buildup.text: Local color: the inherent color of an object in neutral white light (the apple IS red). Observed color: the actual color you SEE under specific lighting conditions (the apple LOOKS purple right now).

discovery.text: Beginners paint local color ‚Äî making the apple red regardless of lighting. Advanced artists paint observed color ‚Äî making the apple whatever color the light conditions dictate. This is what makes paintings glow.

twist.text: Your brain fights you on this. It 'knows' the apple is red and tries to override what your eyes actually see. You have to train yourself to see color, not recognize objects.

climax.text: Try squinting at a scene until you can't identify objects ‚Äî just color patches. That's how to see observed color. The moment you name the object, your brain replaces what you see.

punchline.text: Paint what you see, not what you know. The eye is smarter than the brain.

quiz.question: What is 'observed color'?
options: The color you think an object should be
The actual color you see under specific lighting conditions
The color on a paint tube
The most saturated version of a color
